sn44.11:4.1: At one time Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
sn44.11:4.2: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to him,
sn44.11:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn44.11:4.6: “Master Kaccāna, does a Realized One exist after death?”
sn44.11:4.7: “Vaccha, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:4.9: “Well then, does a Realized One not exist after death?”
sn44.11:4.10: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:5.1: “Well then, does a Realized One both exist and not exist after death?”
sn44.11:5.2: “This has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:5.4: “Well then, does a Realized One neither exist nor not exist after death?”
sn44.11:5.5: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
sn44.11:6.1: “Master Kaccāna, when asked these questions, you say that this has not been declared by the Buddha.
sn44.11:6.13: What’s the cause, what’s the reason why this has not been declared by the Buddha?”
sn44.11:6.14: “In order to describe him as ‘possessing form’ or ‘formless’ or ‘percipient’ or ‘non-percipient’ or ‘neither percipient nor non-percipient’, there must be some cause or reason for doing so. But if that cause and reason were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over,
sn44.11:6.15: how could you describe him in any such terms?”
sn44.11:6.16: “Master Kaccāna, how long has it been since you went forth?”
sn44.11:6.18: “Well, you’ve learned a lot already; and who can say what lies ahead!”
